Bayes' Theorem

  //   Topics: Probability

Named after Thomas Bayes, Bayes’ Theorem determines the likelihood of occurence of an event \(\pmb {A}\), given the occurence of another event \(\pmb {B}\). This is denoted by \(\pmb {P(A \vert B)}\), which reads as “the probability of \(\pmb {A}\) given \(\pmb {B}\)”.

\(\pmb {P(A)}\) and \(\pmb {P(B)}\) are the probabilities of \(\pmb {A}\) and \(\pmb {B}\) occuring without any specific conditions.

\[\pmb { P(A \vert B) = { {P(B \vert A)P(A)} \over P(B) } }\]

For more on conditional probability, see Wikipedia.
